metadata.title: Sensitivity analysis: multilinearity and beyond

sections.text:
Sensitivity methods for the analysis of the outputs of discrete Bayesian networks have been extensively studied and implemented in different software packages. These methods usually focus on the study of sensitivity functions and on the impact of a parameter change to the Chan-Darwiche distance. Although not fully recognized, the majority of these results heavily rely on the multilinear structure of atomic probabilities in terms of the conditional probability parameters associated with this type of network. By defining a statistical model through the polynomial expression of its associated defining conditional probabilities, we develop a unifying approach to sensitivity methods applicable to a large suite of models including extensions of Bayesian networks, for instance context-specific and dynamic ones, and chain event graphs. By then focusing on models whose defining polynomial is multilinear, our algebraic approach enables us to prove that the Chan-Darwiche distance is minimized for a certain class of multi-parameter contemporaneous variations when parameters are proportionally covaried.
Keywords: CD distance, Chain Event Graphs, Covariation, Interpolating Polynomial, Sensitivity Analysis

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Many discrete statistical problems in a variety of domains are nowadays often modeled using Bayesian networks (BNs) [35]. There are now thousands of practical applications of these models [1, 7, 25, 26], which have spawned many useful technical developments: for instance, a variety of fast exact, approximate and symbolic propagation algorithms for the computation of probabilities that exploit the underlying graph structure [14, 16, 17]. Some of these advances are hard-wired into software [9, 28, 32] which further favored the applicability and success of these models.
However, BN modelling would not have experienced such a widespread application without tailored methodologies of model validation, i.e. for checking that a model produces outputs that are in line with current understanding, following a defensible and expected mechanism [19, 38]. Such techniques are now well established for BN models [12, 28, 38, 39]. These techniques are especially fundamental for expert elicited models, where both the probabilities and the covariance structure are defined from the suggestions of domains experts, following knowledge engineering protocols tailored to the BN’s bulding process [34, 40]. We can broadly categorize the validation process in two steps: the first concerns the auditing of the underlying graphical structure; the second, assuming the graph represents a user’s beliefs, checks the impact of the elicited probabilities within this parametric family on outputs of interest. The focus of this paper lies in this second validation phase, usually called a sensitivity analysis.
The most common investigation is the so-called one-way sensitivity analysis, where the impacts of changes of one probability parameter at a time are studied. Analyses where more than one parameter at a time is varied are usually referred to as multi-way. In both cases a complete sensitivity analysis entails the study of Chan-Darwiche (CD) distances [9, 10, 11] and sensitivity functions [13, 21]. The CD distance is used to quantify global changes. It measures how the overall distribution behaves when one (or more) parameter is varied. A great portion of research has focused on identifying parameter changes such that the original and the ‘varied’ BN distributions are close in CD distance [11, 41]. This is minimized when, after a single arbitrary parameter change, other covarying parameters, e.g. those from the same conditional distributions, have the same proportion of the residual probability mass as they originally

had. Sensitivity functions, on the other hand, model local changes with respect to an output of interest. These describe how that output probability varies as one (or potentially more) parameter is allowed to be changed. Although both these concepts can be applied to generic Bayesian analyses, they have almost exclusively been discussed and applied only within the BN literature. This is because the computations of both CD distances and sensitivity functions are particularly straightforward for BN models.
In this paper we introduce a unifying comprehensive framework for one-way analyses by investigating models from a polynomial point of view. Using the notion of an interpolating polynomial [36] we are able to describe a large variety of models based on their polynomial form. We demonstrate that sensitivity methods defined for BNs straightforwardly generalize to any model whose interpolating polynomial is multilinear, for example context-specific BNs [6] and chain event graphs [3, 42]. We will extensively focus on this latter class of asymmetric models which are built by merging certain vertices of a probability tree whose associated probabilities are identified. Both the BN and the context-specific BN model class can be seen as a subset of the class of CEGs, which enables users to model a large variety of asymmetric conditional independences. Methodologies to embellish CEG modeling are now in place, for instance learning algorithms [15], causal reasoning [45] and inference routines [22, 44]. However, sensitivity methods tailored to CEGs have not been introduced yet, which would become fundamental for the application of these models in real-world problems.
By studying sensitivity analysis from a polynomial point of view we are able to consider a much larger class of models for which such methods are not currently available. We investigate the properties of sensitivity analysis in models whose interpolating polynomial is not multilinear, which are usually associated to dynamic settings where probabilities are recursively defined. As we will show below, this difference gives us an even richer class of sensitivity functions, which are not simply linear as in the BN and multilinear one-way case. We further introduce a procedure to compute the CD distance in these models and demonstrate that no unique updating of covarying parameters lead to the smallest distance between the original and the varied distribution.
We then conclude the paper relating multi-way methods in multilinear models, where many parameters are contemporaneously allowed to vary, to one-way methods in models whose interpolating polynomial is non-multilinear. Multi-way methods have not been extensively discussed in the literature: see [5, 10] for some exceptions. Importantly, our approach will allow us to prove that multi-way analyses - usually called in the context of BNs single full conditional probability table (CPT) analyses - where one parameter from each CPT of one vertex of a BN given each configurations of its parents is optimal under proportional covariation in the sense that minimizes the CD distance between the original and the varied distribution. The optimality of this covariation method has been an open problem in the sensitivity analysis literature for quite some time [10]. This result gives a further incentive in investigating sensitivity methods through the polynomial definition of parametric models we introduce next.

sections.heading: 2. Multilinear and polynomial parametric models
sections.text:
In this section we first provide a generic definition of a parametric statistical model together with the notion of interpolating polynomial. We then categorize parametric models according to the form of their interpolating polynomials and show that many commonly used models fall within two classes.
2.1. Parametric models and interpolating polynomials Let Y = (Y1, . . . , Ym) be a random vector with an associated discrete and finite sample space Y, with #Y = n. Although our methods straightforwardly applies when the entries of Y are random vectors, for ease of notation, we henceforth assume its elements are univariate.
Definition 1. Denote by pθ = (pθ(y) | y ∈ Y) the vector of values of a probability mass function pθ : Y → [0, 1] which depends on a choice of parameters θ ∈ Rk. The entries of pθ are called atomic probabilities and the elements y ∈ Y atoms. Definition 2. A discrete parametric statistical model on n ∈ N atoms is a subset PΨ ⊆ ∆n−1 of the n − 1 dimensional probability simplex, where Ψ : Rk → PΨ, θ 7→ pθ, (1) is a bijective map identifying a particular choice of parameters θ ∈ Rk with one vector of atomic probabilities. The map Ψ is called a parametrisation of the model.
The above definition is often encountered in the field of algebraic statistics, where properties of statistical models are studied using techniques from algebraic geometry and commutative computer algebra, among others [18, 37]. We next follow [23] in extending some standard terminology.
Definition 3. A model PΨ ⊆ ∆n−1 has a monomial parametrisation if
pθ(y) = θαy , for all y ∈ Y,
where αy ∈ Nk0 denotes a vector of exponents and θαy = θ α1,y 1 · · · θ αk,y k is a monomial. Then equation (1) is a monomial map and θαy ∈ Rk[Θ], for all y ∈ Y. Here Θ = {θ1, . . . , θk} is the set of indeterminates and Rk[Θ] is the polynomial ring over the field R.
For models entertaining a monomial parametrisation the network polynomial we introduce in Definition 4 below concisely captures the model structure and provides a platform to answer inferential queries [17, 22].
Definition 4. The network polynomial of a model PΨ with monomial parametrisation Ψ is given by cPΨ (θ, λ) = ∑ y∈Y pθ(y) = ∑ α∈A λyθ α,
where λy is an indicator function for the atom y and A = {αy | y ∈ Y} ⊂ Nk0.
Probabilities of events in the underlying sigma-field can be computed from the network polynomial by setting equal to one the indicator function of atoms associated to that event. In the following it will be convenient to work with a special case of the network polynomial where all the indicator functions are set to one.
Definition 5. The interpolating polynomial of a model PΨ with monomial parametrisation Ψ is given by the sum of all atomic probabilities, cPΨ (θ) = ∑ α∈A θα.
2.2. Multilinear models
In this work we will mostly focus on parametric models whose interpolating polynomial is multilinear.
Definition 6. We say that a parametric model PΨ is multilinear if its associated interpolating polynomial is multilinear, i.e. if A ⊆ {0, 1}k.
We note here that a great portion of well-known non-dynamic graphical models are multilinear. We explicitly show below that this is the case for BNs, context-specific BNs [6] and certain CEG models. In addition, decomposable undirected graphs [30] and probabilistic chain graphs [20] can be defined to have a monomial parametrisation whose associated interpolating polynomial is multilinear.
2.2.1. Bayesian networks For an m ∈ N, let [m] = {1, . . . , m}. We denote with Yi, i ∈ [m], a generic discrete random variable and with Yi = {0, . . . , mi} its associated sample space. For an A ⊆ [m], we let YA = (Yi)i∈A and YA = ×i∈AYi.
Definition 7. A BN over a discrete random vector Y[m] consists of
• m − 1 conditional independence statements of the form Yi ⊥ Y[i−1] |YΠi , where Πi ⊆ [i − 1];
• a directed acyclic graph (DAG) G with vertex set V(G) = {Yi : i ∈ [m]} and edge set E(G) = {(Yi, Y j) : j ∈ [m], i ∈ Π j};
• conditional probabilities θi jπ = Pr(Yi = j | YΠi = π) for every j ∈ Yi, π ∈ YΠi and i ∈ [m].
From [10] we know that for any atom y ∈ Y[m] its associated monomial in the network polynomial can be written as
pθ(y) = ∏
y∼{i j,π} λi jθi jπ,
where ∼ denotes the compatibility relation among instantiations.
Lemma 1. From [17, 22], the interpolating polynomial of a BN model can be written as cBN(θ) = ∑
y∈Y[m] ∏ y∼{i j,π} θi jπ. (2)
From Equation (2) we can immediately deduce the following.
Proposition 1. A BN is a multilinear parametric model, whose interpolating polynomial is homogeneous with monomials of degree m.
Example 1. Suppose a newborn is at risk of acquiring a disease and her parents are offered a screening test (Y1) which can be either positive (Y1 = 2), negative (Y1 = 2) or inconclusive (Y1 = 0). Given that the newborn either acquired (Y2 = 1) or not (Y2 = 0) the disease, her parents can then decide whether or not to give her a vaccine to prevent a relapse (Y3 = 1 and Y3 = 0, respectively). We assume that the parents’ decision about the vaccine does not depend on the screening test if the newborn contracted the disease, and that the probability of choosing vaccination is the same for inconclusive and positive screening evidence when the newborn does not acquire the disease.
The above situation can be described, with some loss of information, by the BN in Figure 1, with probabilities

2.2.2. Context-specific Bayesian networks In practice it has been recognized that often conditional independence statements do not hold over the whole sample space of certain conditioning variables but only for a subset of this, usually referred to as a context. A variety of methods have been introduced to embellish a BN with additional independence statements that hold only over contexts. A BN equipped with such embellishments is usually called context-specific BN. Here we consider the representation known as context specific independence (CSI)-trees and introduced in [6].
Example 2. Consider the medical problem in Example 1. Using the introduced notation, we notice that by assumption, for each k = 0, 1, the probabilities θ3k211i , θ3k211 are equal for all i = 0, 1, 2. Also θ3k2010 = θ3k2012 , θ3k201 are equal. These equations can be represented by the CSI-tree in Figure 2, where the inner nodes are random variables and the leaves are entries of the CPTs of one vertex. The tree shows that, if Y2 = 1 then no matter what the value of Y1 is, the CPT for Y3 = k will be equal to θ3k211. Furthermore, as shown in the left hand side of the tree, the probability that Y3 = k is equal when {Y2 = 0, Y1 = 0} and {Y2 = 0, Y1 = 2}. The network polynomial of the context-specific BN described by the DAG in Figure 1 and the CSI-tree in Figure 2 corresponds to the polynomial in equation (2) where the appropriate indeterminates are substituted with θ3k211 and θ3k201. This polynomial is again multilinear and homogeneous, just like for all context-specific BNs embellished with CSI-trees.
2.2.3. Staged trees and chain event graphs We next consider models represented by trees. These are able to capture more general asymmetric conditional independence statements. Let T = (V , E), with E ⊂ V × V , be a directed rooted tree where each inner vertex v ∈ V , also called situation, has at least two children. In this graph representation, the set of root-to-leaf paths RT is in oneto-one correspondence with the sample space of an underlying model. We write r = (e | e ∈ E(r)) ∈ RT for one such path, which is a sequence of edges E(r) ⊂ E. We assume that every edge e = (v, v′) ∈ E has a primitive probability label θe ∈ (0, 1) which can be thought of as the transition probability from v to v′. These labels are assumed to obey local summing-to-unity constraints in the sense that ∑ e∈E(v) θe = 1 where E(v) ⊆ E is the set of edges emanating from v ∈ V . For a situation v, F (v) = (v, E(v)) and θv = (θe | e ∈ E(v)) are called a floret and a (floret) parameter vector, respectively. Set ΘT = {θv | v ∈ V} to be the set of parameter vectors associated to a tree. Then, the probability of an atom in the model space is given by the product of primitive probabilities along the edges of its path representation, pθ(r) = ∏ e∈E(r) θe. We call the pair (T , ΘT ) a probability tree.
Definition 8. We call a probability tree a staged tree if for some v, v′ ∈ V , the corresponding floret parameter vectors are identified θv = θv′ . Then, v and v′ are said to be in the same stage.
Being in the same stage thus implies that the associated transition probabilities of two different vertices are identified. Thus, staged trees depict information on context-specific conditional independence of the type discussed in Section 2.2.2. When drawing a tree, vertices in the same stage are equally framed in order to have a visual counterpart for that information. A second partition of the situations of a tree is as follows.
Definition 9. We say that two situations v and v′ are in the same position if the induced subtrees with roots v and v′ have the same graph and the same vertex framing. We let W denote the set of positions of a staged tree.
Note that all leaves are trivially in the same stage, denoted w∞. Two situations in the same position are by definition also in the same stage, whilst it does not necessary follow that two situations in the same stage are also in the same position.
Example 3. Consider the problem described in Example 1. The associated BN representation could be transformed into a staged tree where all the vertices are in different stages. However, if we straightforwardly build a staged tree for the situation described in the example, we can visually model all the asymmetric conditional independence constraints as shown in Figure 3. In particular in this case the stages, which are also positions, are
w1 = {v1}, w2 = {v2}, w3 = {v3}, w4 = {v4}, w5 = {v5, v9}, w6 = {v6, v8, v10}, w7 = {v7}.
Although staged trees have the capability of modeling much more complex problems than BNs, their size usually becomes unmanageable when the sample space grows moderately. However, a convenient representation of a staged tree model is via a CEG [3, 42], which is less cluttered and can more concisely describe its conditional independence statements.
Definition 10. A CEG C = C(T ) is the graph obtained by collapsing a staged tree T into its positions. Its vertex set, V(C), is equal to W∪{w∞}, where positions in the same stage are equally framed. Its edge set, E(C), is such that there is an edge (wi, w j), wi, w j ∈W, for every edge from a generic vertex vi ∈ wi to any vertex v j ∈ w j.
Example 4. Figure 4 shows the CEG representation of the staged tree in Figure 3.
Just as for staged trees, the set of root-to-leaf paths RC of a CEG is in one-to-one correspondence with the sample space of the underlying model. Note that here two different paths might go through the same sequence of positions, but not through the exactly same sequence of edges. We write r = (e | e ∈ E(r)) ∈ RC for one such path, which is a sequence of edges E(r) ∈ E(C). The CEG inherits from the associated staged trees the primitive probabilities θe ∈ (0, 1), describing the likelihood of going from position w to w′, for e = (w, w′). The probability of an atom is again simply the product of the primitive probabilities along the edges of its paths, πθ(r) = ∏ e∈E(r) θe.
Of special interest in this context are edge-centred events Λ(e) = {r ∈ RC | e ∈ e, e ∈ E(r)}, for e ⊆ E(C) and e = (w, w′) ∈ e, which collect all atoms in the sample space which pass from position w to w′. Position-centred events Λ(w) = {r ∈ RC |w ∈ w, (·, w) ∈ E(r)}, for w ⊂ W, collect all atoms which reached a position w ∈ w. A CEG is not only very expressive for describing how certain events might unfold, but its graph can also embed formal conditional independences. For a position w ∈ V(C), let Y(w) be a variable whose state space Y(w) can be identified with the set of w → w∞ subpaths. Let Z(w) be a variable whose state space Z(w) can be identified with the set of w1 → w subpaths, w1 being the root of the CEG. Then, from [46], we have that
Y(w) ⊥ Z(w) | Λ(w),
which can be read as ‘variables defined downstream of w are independent of variables defined upstream, given the event Λ(w)’.
Just as for BNs, we can easily express the form of the interpolating polynomial of a CEG model as follows:
Lemma 2. The interpolating polynomial of a CEG can be written as cC(θ) = ∑ r∈RC πθ(r) = ∑ r∈RC ∏ e∈E(r) θe.
In [22] we introduced the CEG network polynomial and showed that its derivatives can be used to answer various inferential queries. We extensively discussed there the advantages of the symbolic representation of CEGs over the one of BNs: for instance, the network polynomial of the CEG has most often less terms and terms of lower degree than the one of the associated BN representation. For a more extensive comparison of the two polynomial forms see [22].
Example 5. Letting θi j denote the primitive probability associated to j-th emanating edge from position wi as shown in Figure 4, the interpolating polynomial of the CEG in Figure 4 equals, by Lemma 2,
cC(θ) = θ11θ21θ51 + θ11θ21θ52 + θ11θ22θ61 + θ11θ22θ62 + θ12θ41θ51 + θ12θ41θ52+ θ12θ42θ61 + θ12θ42θ52 + θ13θ31θ61 + θ13θ31θ62 + θ13θ32θ71 + θ13θ32θ72. (3)
Although many CEGs have an associated multilinear polynomial, as the one in Example 5, this does not necessarily need to be the case. The notion of stages gives enough flexibility to build models with non-multilinear interpolating polynomials. This happens whenever two positions in the same stage are along the same path.
Definition 11. A CEG with multilinear interpolating polynomial is said to be square-free [23].
2.3. Non-multilinear models Having discussed multilinear models, we now introduce more general structures which are often encountered in dynamic settings. Although many more models have this property, for instance dynamic chain graphs [2] and dynamic chain event graphs [4], for the purposes of this paper we focus here on two important model classes: dynamic Bayesian networks (DBNs) [33] and non-square-free CEGs.
2.3.1. Dynamic Bayesian networks DBNs extend the BN framework to dynamic and stochastic domains. As often in practice, we consider only stationary, feed-forward DBNs respecting the first order Markov assumption with a finite horizon T ∈ N, see e.g. [27]. This assumes that probabilities do not vary when shifted on time (stationarity), that current states only depend on the previous time point (first-order Markov assumption) and that contemporaneous variable cannot directly affect each other (feed-forward). These DBNs can be simply described by an initial distribution over the first time point and a BN having as vertex set two generic time slices. Such latter BN is usually called 2-Time slice Bayesian Network (2-TBN). Let {Y(t)}t∈[T ] = {Yi(t) : i ∈ [m]}t∈[T ] be a time series. Definition 12. A 2-TBN for {Y(t)}t∈[T ] is a BN with DAG G such that V(G) = {Yi(t), Yi(t + 1) : i ∈ [m]}, any vertex Yi(t) has no parents and there are no edges (Yi(r), Y j(r)), i, j ∈ [m], r = t, t + 1, t ∈ [T − 1].
Definition 13. A DBN for the time series {Y(t)}t∈[T ] is a pair (G,G′), such that G is a BN with vertex set V(G) = {Yi(1) : i ∈ [m]}, and G′ is a 2-TBN such that its vertex set V(G′) is equal to {Yi(t), Yi(t + 1) : i ∈ [m]}.
Example 6. Consider the problem of Example 1 and suppose the newborn can acquire the disease once a year. Suppose further that the screening test and the vaccine are available for kids up to three years old. This scenario can be modeled by a DBN with time horizon T = 3, where Yi(t), i, t ∈ [3], corresponds to the variable Yi of Example 1 measured in the t-th year. Suppose that the probabilities of parents choosing the screening test and vaccination depend on whether or not the newborn acquired the disease in the previous year only. Furthermore, there is evidence that kids have a higher chance of contracting the disease if they were sick the previous year, whilst a lower chance if vaccination was chosen. This situation can be described by the DBN in Figure 5 where at time t = 1 the correlation structure of the non-dynamic problem is assumed.

sections.heading: 3. Sensitivity analysis in multilinear models
sections.text:
We can now formalize sensitivity analysis techniques for multilinear parametric models. We focus mainly on one-way sensitivity methods. Although some preliminary work on multi-way analyses is now available [5, 10], the computational cost of such investigations have limited their use in practice. However, in Section 6 we present some novel results for this type of analyses. We now demonstrate that all the results about one-way sensitivity analysis in BN models straightforwardly extend to multilinear parametric models and therefore hold under much weaker assumptions about the structure of both the sample space and the underlying conditional independences.
3.1. Covariation In one-way analyses one parameter within a parametrisation of a model is varied. When this is done, then some of the remaining parameters need to be varied as well to respect the sum-to-one condition, so that the resulting measure is a probability measure. In the binary case this is straightforward, since the second parameter will be equal to one minus the other. But in generic discrete finite cases there are various considerations the user needs to take into account, as reviewed below.
Let θi ∈ Θ be the parameter varied to θ̃i and suppose this is associated to a random variable YC in the random vector Y. Let ΘC = {θ1, . . . , θi, . . . , θr} ⊆ Θ be the subset of the parameter set including θi describing the probability distribution of YC and whose elements need to respect the sum to one condition. For instance ΘC would include the entries of a CPT for a fixed combination of the parent variables in a BN model or the floret parameters in a CEG. Suppose further these parameters are indexed according to their values, i.e. θ1 ≤ · · · ≤ θi ≤ · · · ≤ θr. From [41] we then have the following definition.
Definition 14. Let θi ∈ ΘC be varied to θ̃i. A covariation scheme σ(θ j, θ̃i) : [0, 1]2 → [0, 1] is a function that takes as input the value of both θ̃i and θ j ∈ ΘC and returns an updated value for θ j denoted as θ̃ j.
Different covariation schemes may entertain different properties which, depending on the domain of application, might be more or less desirable. We now list some of these properties from [41].
Definition 15. In the notation of Definition 14, we say that a covariation scheme σ(θ j, θ̃i) is • valid, if ∑ j∈[r] σ(θ j, θ̃i) = 1; • impossibility preserving, if for any parameter θ j = 0, j , i, we have that σ(θ j, θ̃i) = 0;
• order preserving, if σ(θ1, θ̃i) ≤ · · · ≤ σ(θ j, θ̃i) ≤ · · · ≤ σ(θr, θ̃i);
• identity preserving, if σ(θ j, θi) = θ j, ∀ j ∈ [r];
• linear, if σ(θ j, θ̃i) = γ jθ̃i + δ j, for γ j ∈ [0, 1] and δ j ∈ (−1, 1). Of course any covariation scheme needs to be valid, otherwise the resulting measure is not a probability measure and any inference from the model would be misleading. Applying a linear scheme is very natural: if for instance γ j = δ j, then σ(θ j, θ̃i) = γ j(1 − θ̃i) and the scheme assigns a proportion γ j of the remaining probability mass 1 − θ̃i to the remaining parameters. Following [41] we now introduce a number of frequently applied covariation schemes.
Definition 16. In the notation of Definition 14, we define

Under proportional covariation, to all the covarying parameters is assigned the same proportion of the remaining probability mass as these originally had. Although this scheme is not order preserving, it maintains the order among the covarying parameters. The uniform scheme on the other hand gives the same amount of the remaining mass to all covarying parameters. In addition, although the order preserving scheme is the only one that entertains the order preserving property, this limits the possible variations allowed. Furthermore, in this scheme the last and biggest parameter θr cannot be varied: however this is not a very limiting constraint since we can always write one parameter as one minus the sum of the others. Note that this scheme is not only simply linear, but more precisely piece-wise linear, i.e. a function composed of straight-line sections.
All the schemes in Definition 16 are domain independent and therefore can be applied with no prior knowledge about the application of interest. Other schemes, for instance domain dependent or non-linear, have been defined, but these are not of interest for the theory we develop here.
3.2. Sensitivity functions Sensitivity functions describe the effect of varying one parameter on the probability of an event YT ⊆ Y of interest. A sensitivity function fyT (θ̃i) equals the probability Pr(Y ∈ YT ) , pθ(yT ) and is a function in θ̃i, where θi is varied to θ̃i. Our parametric definition of a statistical model enables us to explicitly express these as functions of the covariation scheme for any multilinear model. Recall that A = {αy | y ∈ Y} and let T = {αy | y ∈ YT }. Let AC ,TC ⊂ {0, 1}k be the subsets of A and T respectively including the exponents where the entry associated to an indeterminate in ΘC is not zero, AC j ⊆ AC and TC j ⊆ TC the subsets including the exponents such that the entry relative to θ j is not zero. However, we have proven here that this feature is shared amongst all models having a multilinear interpolating polynomial. In BNs the computation of the coefficients α and β is particularly fast since for these models computationally efficient propagation techniques have been established. But these exist, sometimes less efficiently, for other models as well (see e.g. [44] for CEGs and staged trees). Within our symbolic definition, we note however that once the exponent sets TC− j , j ∈ [r], are identified, then one can simply plug-in the values of the indeterminates to compute these coefficients.

3.3. The Chan-Darwiche distance Whilst sensitivity functions study local changes, CD distances describe global changes in distributions [11]. These can be used to study by how much two vectors of atomic probabilities vary in their distributional assumptions if one arises from the other via a covariation scheme. We are then interested in the global impact of that local change. We start by defining the distance.
Definition 17. Let pθ, pθ̃ ∈ PΨ two vectors of values of two probability mass functions from the same parametric model PΨ. The CD distance between pθ and pθ̃, CD(pθ, pθ̃), is defined as
CD(pθ, pθ̃) = ln maxy∈Y pθ̃(y) pθ(y) − ln min y∈Y pθ̃(y) pθ(y) , (10)
where 0/0 is defined as 1.
Although this has not been recognized in the literature yet, we note that the CD distance coincides with the DeRobertis distance, used in robustness studies in Bayesian inference [24, 43]. This has the very convenient property for Bayesian inference of being invariant to Bayesian evidential updating: the distance between two distributions a priori and after both have been updated using some data points does not change. It has also been noted that in sensitivity analysis in BNs, if one parameter of one CPT is varied, then distance between the original and the varied BN equals the distance between the original and the varied CPT [11, 43]. We demonstrate now that this property is more generally entertained by any multilinear model.

3.4. Kullback-Leibler divergence Although the CD distance is widely used in sensitivity analyses, comparisons between two distributions are usually performed by computing the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence [29].
Definition 18. Let pθ, pθ̃ ∈ PΨ two vectors of values of two probability mass functions from the same parametric model PΨ. The KL distance between pθ and pθ̃, KL(pθ, pθ̃), is defined as

sections.heading: 4. Sensitivity analysis in square-free CEGs

The previous section has formalized sensitivity methods in multilinear parametric models and shown that these generalize the results for BN models. As an illustration of these techniques to a different multilinear model we now consider the class of CEGs. Whilst in multilinear models the sum-to-one condition needs to be respected in the sets ΘC and in BNs this needs to hold for CPTs, in CEG models (conditional) probability distributions are associated to its florets: probabilities associated to edges emanating from the same position must sum to one. So when varying one parameter from one floret, not only the parameters associated to emanating edges from the same position needs to covary, but also those of edges from positions in the same stage. Formally, for an edge ei ∈ E(C), let ei be the set of edges whose primitive probabilities are identified with θei and wei the set of positions w such that for every e ∈ ei, e = (w, ·). Suppose each element of wei has si emanating edges labeled e j, j ∈ [si], and let w̄ei be the complement of wei in W.
4.1. Sensitivity functions for square-free CEGs
Suppose we are interested in the probability of an event A associated to a set of root-to-leaf paths RA as a function of θ̃ei , the varied version of θei .

These probabilities can also be visually deduced from the underlying graph of the CEG since its root-to-leaf paths coincide with the model’s sample space. We illustrate the intuitiveness of these operations in CEGs with the following example.
Example 11. Suppose the definition of the CEG in Figure 4 is completed with the probability specifications in Table 2. Suppose we are interested in the event that the newborn is healthy as a function of an inconclusive screening test. This event is described by the root-to-leaf paths going through an edge labeled ‘healthy’ and the sets ei and wei include one element only: (w1, w2) and w1 respectively. Furthermore the floret associated to w1 has two other emanating edges (w1, w3) and (w1, w4) whose associated probabilities need to covary.
To compute the sensitivity function we need to derive the probabilities in the coefficients in equation (13). Note that = 0 since there are no paths not going through w1, the root of the CEG. This also implies Pr(Λ(wei )) = 1. Lastly, the probabilities Pr(A | Λ(e j)), j ∈ [si], correspond to θkl, k = 2, 3, 4, l = 1, 2, the probability that the newborn is healthy once position wk is reached. Thus

The form of the sensitivity function under different covariation schemes is shown in Figure 7. We can notice that the choice of this scheme has a significant impact on the probability of interest. Whilst the sensitivity function is increasing for a proportional scheme, it is decreasing for the uniform one. Under an order preserving scheme the behavior of the sensitivity function is decreasing in (0, 0.3), the original value of the varied parameter, and then increasing in (0.3, 0.5), where 0.5 is the maximum value θ11 can take for the scheme to be valid. All these functions, because square-free CEGs are multilinear models, are (piece-wise) linear as specified by Theorem 1.
When the covariation scheme is linear then also the sensitivity function of a square-free CEG is linear, as specified in Corollary 1.

Proof. This follows by substituting the definition of a linear covariation scheme into equation (12).
Interestingly, for non-squared CEGs the posterior sensitivity function conditional on events of the form Λ(w), indicating that a certain position has been reached, is not rational but again a simple linear function. This is because this conditional probability can be computed from the induced subgraph of the CEG having as root the position w. This subgraph is again a CEG. Since probabilities over this subgraph are multilinear, then sensitivity functions will be linear.
Example 12. Suppose we are interested in the probability that the newborn is healthy knowing that the screening test result was inconclusive. This probability can be computed from the subgraph of the CEG in Figure 4 having as root w2 and edges along paths between w2 and w∞. This probability is then simply θ21.

For multilinear models we have been able to provide a unifying framework to perform various sensitivity analyses by deducing closed forms for both sensitivity functions and the CD distance. Unfortunately, this is not possible for non-multilinear parametric models because these will depend on the degree of both the indeterminate to be varied and the covaried parameters, which is not necessarily equal to one. However, representing the model through its interpolating polynomial will enable us to study central properties of both sensitivity functions and CD distances. As in Section 3, we let θi ∈ ΘC be varied to θ̃i, where ΘC = {θ j : j ∈ [r]} is the set of parameters including θi which need to respect the sum-to-one condition.

sections.heading: 6. Multi-way sensitivity analysis in multilinear models
sections.text:
So far we have concentrated on one-way sensitivity analysis only, the most commonly performed in practice. We now consider multi-way sensitivity methods where more than one parameter is varied contemporaneously. We first focus on a specific type of analysis, usually referred to as fully single CPT analysis. In this type of method one parameter from each probability table given a configuration of parents, θi jπ, is varied in a BN model. So, for instance, if a vertex has n possible configurations of parent variables, then these n parameters are varied.
6.1. Full single conditional probability table analysis We now generalize the full single CPT methods from BNs to general multilinear models. This type of analysis is simpler than other multi-way methods since the parameters varied/covaried never appear in the same monomial of the BN interpolating polynomial. So we now find an analogous to this CPT analysis in multilinear models which has the same property. Suppose we vary n parameters θ1i , . . . , θni and denote by Θ j = {θ j1 , . . . , θ jr j }, j ∈ [n], the set of parameters including θ ji and associated to the same (conditional) random variable. Assume these sets are such that ∩ j∈[n]Θ j = ∅. Note that a collection of such sets can not only be associated to CPTs of one vertex given different parent configurations, but also, for instance, to positions along the same cut in a CEG [46].
Recall that T ⊆ A is the exponent set associated to the event described by YT . Let now T j ⊆ {0, 1}k be the subset of T including the exponents where the entry associated to an indeterminate in Θ j is not zero. Given this observation, the results of Section 3.2 can be generalized straightforwardly to full single CPT analyses by simply adapting the notation and summing over the index j of the spaces Θ j.

6.2. Multi-way analysis Our polynomial approach, as shown in the previous section, has proven useful in investigating the full single CPT case. We now discuss how more general multi-way sensitivity analysis methods for multilinear methods can be described within our framework.
Example 17. Consider the vaccination example described by the CEG in Figure 4 and suppose we are now interested in the probability of vaccination as a function of both the probability of an inconclusive test θ11 and the probability of the newborn being healthy given an inconclusive test θ21. From the interpolating polynomial of this CEG give in equation (3) we can deduce that
fyT (θ̃11, θ̃21) = αθ̃11θ̃21 + βθ̃11 + γσ(θ12, θ̃11) + δσ(θ13, θ̃11), (18)
where α, β, γ, δ ∈ [0, 1]. Thus, in this case the sensitivity function is not a simple linear function, but has an interaction term αθ̃11θ̃21. The interpolating polynomial however gives a simple tool to identify the form of the sensitivity function in multilinear models. We plot these functions in Figure 9 under the proportional and the uniform scheme. Both exhibit an almost linear behaviour and are increasing in both indeterminates. These graphs can be used in more refined sensitivity analyses to investigate the effects of contemporaneous parameter changes.
Note that the indeterminates in equation (18) coincide with those monomials φ of Proposition 5 that have an impact on the CD distance. Therefore we can interpret the computation of the CD distance for multilinear models, including BNs, for multi-way analyses as the computation of the distance in one-way analyses for non-multilinear models. Example 15 would therefore suggest that the proportional covariation scheme is not optimal in this context. However, we notice that the monomials from multi-way analyses in multilinear models are a subset of those arising from non-multilinear models: although these can be of an arbitrary degree, each indeterminate of the monomial will have exponent one by construction. Therefore, there is no conclusive proof of the non-optimality of the proportional scheme in multi-way analyses for multilinear models and BNs.

sections.heading: 7. Discussion
sections.text:
The definition of a parametric model through its interpolating polynomial has proven useful to investigate how changes in the input probabilities affect an output of interest. We have been able to demonstrate that standard results for BN models are valid for a large number of other models, for instance context-specific BNs and square-free CEGs. Then, the flexibility of the interpolating polynomial representation enabled us to investigate an even larger class of models, for instance DBNs and non square-free CEGs, extending sensitivity methods to dynamic settings. In this framework both sensitivity functions and CD distances exhibit different properties than in the simpler multilinear case, with the potential of even more informative sensitivity investigations. We then proved the optimality of the proportional covariation scheme in full conditional CPT analyses not only for BNs but also multilinear models.
In this paper we have focused on discrete probabilistic models, but the notion of an interpolating polynomial can be generalized to both continuous and decision-analytic domains. In particular, this could be defined over the polynomial ring whose indeterminates are some of the (conditional) moments of the random variables, the ones that are formally required to compute an expected utility function. Variation of the value of the moments could be implemented to study the robustness of decision making in continuous domains, defining generalizations of the methods in [31].
Lastly, as customary in this type of sensitivity analyses, our approach assumes that the models’ probabilities are known. However, both in machine learned and expert elicited models this will not be the case and uncertainty measures associated to these probabilities are often available. We are starting to investigate methods that take into account the uncertainty about the probability parameters and that explore the effects of treating these numbers as known.

metadata.abstractText: Sensitivity methods for the analysis of the outputs of discrete Bayesian networks have been extensively studied and implemented in different software packages. These methods usually focus on the study of sensitivity functions and on the impact of a parameter change to the Chan-Darwiche distance. Although not fully recognized, the majority of these results heavily rely on the multilinear structure of atomic probabilities in terms of the conditional probability parameters associated with this type of network. By defining a statistical model through the polynomial expression of its associated defining conditional probabilities, we develop a unifying approach to sensitivity methods applicable to a large suite of models including extensions of Bayesian networks, for instance context-specific and dynamic ones, and chain event graphs. By then focusing on models whose defining polynomial is multilinear, our algebraic approach enables us to prove that the Chan-Darwiche distance is minimized for a certain class of multi-parameter contemporaneous variations when parameters are proportionally covaried.
